children.subject: How, man? It demands more time than 189 and 168 combined...
I think it might depend on what professor.. Wasn't a heavy workload but conceptually a bit difficult for me IMO.
I took it with Hellerstein... tests weren't that bad and the hw's (aka projects) were mostly straightforward.
Have no idea about the EE classes, but 186 was the easiest CS class I've taken at Cal.

history.content: While 186 is generally considered a simple design course, EE128 is a bit heftier, and EE143 and EECS151 are notorious for their gargantuan workloads that come with their lab reports and projects, respectively.  Highly advised not to take all of them in one semester.

children.subject:
EE128 could eat up your time, especially the weekly lab. The pre-lab on average takes 4-5 hours for my group, and the actual lab takes around 3 hours more or less, depending on whether the system you build works or not. There is weekly homework that should not be underestimated as well. In addition, when I took this class, everything was graded based on correctness. This adds on to the overall effort you would want to spend on the course.

Have no idea about EE143 and EE186.

I will be taking EE151, and plan on reserving 30 hours/week for its lab section.

To sum up, I would say take 128, 151, 186 (this is already a heavy schedule).
Can you comment on why the lab reports would need ~20 hrs?

The first lab report just takes forever.  If you want specifics, in addition to other conceptual questions, you have calculate and draw the actual dimensions and dopant profiles for every step in the fabrication process.  The dopant profile itself is extremely difficult since for several of the steps there are no actual analytical answers, and you have to create some numerical procedure to solve the problem.  This takes a lot of time.  The 2nd lab report could be done quickly, in a day, if you and your partner took/are taking EE130 (it's just about characterizing and explaining all your devices).  Otherwise you'll have to do some extra research yourself.

EE143 has almost no time commitment until the end.  Then lab reports at the end easily take ~20 hrs minimum each, and only if you are really good (there are two).  And 151's project is crazy.  There's a reason most people take it as their only project class in a semester.

history.content: I am considering doing EE128, EE143, EECS151 and CS186 in Spring 2017. I really like these classes and surprisingly found out the professors that are going to teach these classes in spring 2017 are awesome. Is it doable? Would it kill my GPA? I once did CS70, 61C, MATH54, and EE16A in the same semester and got out just fine. But I understand that upper divs are different from lower divs. I will probably be graduating in Spring 2017. Any advice would be appreciated.
history.subject: How doable is 4 design courses in the same semester?
